title: 5 dead in  exceptionally  strong storm in Houston
message:
5 dead in 'exceptionally' strong storm in HoustonAt least five people were killed when a powerful wind storm tore through Houston on Thursday night, officials said.
Straight-line winds peaked at around 100 mph in downtown Houston, and residents told ABC News the winds sounded like a freight train.
Houston Mayor John Whitmire urged residents to stay home Friday following the "exceptionally" strong storm, noting 2,500 traffic lights are not functioning.
The statement also said President Biden had directed the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) "to coordinate Federal recovery operations in the affected areas."
The storm in Houston is now over, allowing residents to begin to cleaning up on Friday.

title: Corps shuts dams at Waco , Whitney to protect downstream
message:
The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers on Friday halted water releases from Lake Waco and other flooded reservoirs in surrounding counties to relieve flooding far downstream in the Houston area.
Lake Waco remained 15.8 feet above its conservation pool of 462 feet above sea level after heavy rains in recent weeks.
Corps of Engineers officials at the three lakes work together to determine release rates, Lake Waco manager Mike Champagne said.
In Waco, Champagne said downstream flooding has hindered the amount of water Lake Waco can release, and it will likely be several days before the dam is opened again.
Both lakes are also Corps of Engineers flood control reservoirs that empty into tributaries of the Brazos River.

title: Active hurricane season could have  detrimental impact  on home insurance
message:
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — The predictions for this upcoming hurricane season are serious with numerous storms predicted.
It's creating concern over what the season could do to Florida's insurance costs.
WPTV Mark Friedlander shares his thoughts on what an active hurricane season could mean for insurance costs in Florida.
"Large loss events always impact insurance markets, no matter how strong those insurance markets are," Friedlander said.
"If you have a heavy volume of loss activity during hurricane season, it's going to change the dynamics."

title: Houston tornado : AccuWeather estimates windstorm damage across 4th - largest US city , metropolitan at $5 billion to $7 billion
message:
Deadly Houston windstorm estimated to have caused $5B to $7B in damage, AccuWeather tells ABC13The storm that pounded Houston, the fourth-largest U.S. city, caused between at least $5 billion worth of damage, AccuWeather preliminarily reports.
The storm that pounded Houston, the fourth-largest U.S. city, caused between at least $5 billion worth of damage, AccuWeather preliminarily reports.
The storm that pounded Houston, the fourth-largest U.S. city, caused between at least $5 billion worth of damage, AccuWeather preliminarily reports.
The storm that pounded Houston, the fourth-largest U.S. city, caused between at least $5 billion worth of damage, AccuWeather preliminarily reports.
AccuWeather, an Eyewitness News partner, revealed a price tag of $5 billion to $7 billion for the damage caused when a powerful storm line pushed across the Houston metropolitan area.

title: Houston storm : At least 4 killed , more than 700 , 000 without power across Texas
message:
(HOUSTON) — At least four people were killed when an “exceptionally” strong storm tore through Houston on Thursday night, according to Mayor John Whitmire.
The winds — which reached 78 mph — sounded like a freight train, Houston residents told ABC News.
Houston schools are closed on Friday and more than 770,000 customers lost power across the state.
The mayor said Houston is in “recovery mode.”“Please … stay away from downtown — it’s dangerous.
The storm in Houston is now over, allowing residents to begin to cleaning up on Friday.

title: National - Carroll Broadcasting Inc .
message:
Getty Images - STOCK(HOUSTON) -- At least five people were killed when a powerful storm tore through Houston on Thursday night, officials said.
Straight-line winds peaked at around 100 mph in downtown Houston, and residents told ABC News the winds sounded like a freight train.
The winds were so powerful, Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said they were comparable to Hurricane Alicia in 1983.
Houston Mayor John Whitmire urged residents to stay home Friday following the "exceptionally" strong storm, noting 2,500 traffic lights are not functioning.
The storm in Houston is now over, allowing residents to begin to cleaning up on Friday.

title: 7 dead in Houston area after storms , 100 - mph winds
message:
“This kind of wind is something we have not seen in Harris County since Hurricane Alicia in 1983,” Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo, the top government executive in the county, said at a news conference Friday.
Hurricane Alicia was a small hurricane but was a Category 3 when it made landfall near San Luis Pass on Aug. 18, 1983.
Houston Mayor John Whitmire said that the city experienced “an exceptionally strong storm" Thursday evening.
He compared the winds to Hurricane Ike that struck in 2008, and said there was "considerable damage downtown."
Trees crashed onto homes and winds ripped away parts of houses in other parts of the city.

title: Deadly storms : Here what weather icon Frank Billingsley thinks hit Houston last night
message:
There were 130 wind reports from Thursday evening’s storm in Houston, indicating the presence of a derecho.
The National Weather Service will make the final determination, but Houston weather icon Frank Billingsley suspects the weather phenomenon that roared through downtown Houston and its north and northwestern suburbs Thursday evening, killing at least 4 people, might have been a derecho.
IMAGES: Daylight illuminates just how severe the storm that hit Houston wasBillingsley, Chief Meteorologist for Houston NBC affiliate KPRC 2, has been forecasting in Houston for nearly 30 years.
If you look at severe storm reports across Texas yesterday, they show a long line of blue dots, which represent high wind reports.
The National Weather Service Storm Prediction Center notched 130 wind reports during the event.

title: Are you prepared for hurricane season ? A study shows your home may not be
message:
WILMINGTON, N.C. (WECT) - We’re just a few weeks away from the official start of the Atlantic Hurricane Season, which begins June 1.
The Insurance Institute for Business and Home Safety released a study noting North Carolina dropped three points in 2024′s “Rating the States” study.
Currently, North Carolina is still using the IRC from 2015.
“That’ll put North Carolina over 15 years behind on building code adoption if nothing changes as we go out toward 2031,” he said.
New Hanover County’s Emergency Management Director Steven Still said there are many things people can do in southeastern North Carolina to prepare ahead of hurricane season.

title: Houston weather : ABC13 identifies tornado , straight - line wind differences through damage in Spring Branch , Cypress , Waller Co .
message:
What's the difference between tornado and straight-line wind damage?
HOUSTON, Texas (KTRK) -- The powerful storms that rolled through southeast Texas on Thursday prompted questions about the differences between straight-line winds and tornadoes.
It's important to note that straight-line winds can be just as dangerous and impactful as a tornado.
When it comes to deciphering straight-line wind damage vs. tornado damage, meteorologists use a few indicators to tell the difference.
And while tornado damage could also include these, there are a few more telltale signs.

title: In case the need arises : How to build an emergency storm kit – Deseret News
message:
The Central North Pacific and Atlantic hurricane season lasts from June 1 to Nov. 30, according to the National Hurricane Center.
Storms occur most often in the spring and summer months, and vary in their length depending on location.
In fact, the National Weather Center has provided a list of storm risk categories, ranging from marginal to high.
The National Weather Center provided a few safety basics: stay inside, away from doors and windows; get down, to the lowest floor available; cover up; stay calm.
Maintaining an emergency kit can also be a helpful way to stay prepared for severe weather, according to the CDC.

title: NWS confirms straight - line winds caused dowtown Houston damage – NBC 5 Dallas - Fort Worth
message:
The National Weather Service Houston says straight-line winds caused all the damage seen downtown as deadly storms blew through southeast Texas Thursday night.
The straight-line winds that ripped through downtown were estimated to have peaked at 100 mph.
The NWS said widespread straight-line winds near Baytown and Galena Park also peaked between 90 mph and 100 mph.
“The environment yesterday across southeast Texas was very favorable for these conditions,” said Maldonado, citing wind shear, a cold front and moisture in the atmosphere.

title: Leon County estimates storm debris cleanup could take up to a month
message:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (WCTV) - Crews in Leon County began storm debris pickup Friday, a week after three tornadoes swept through the local area.
County officials believe it could take up to a month for storm debris cleanup to be completed around the capital city.
As of Friday morning, crews have picked up 10,000 cubic yards of debris which they said is about half of what was collected last year after Hurricane Idalia.
The director of Community Relations and Resilience of Leon County, Matt Cavell, said in all the years of responding to tornados and hurricanes, the county hasn’t seen damage on this scale before.
We had a lot of debris in the front yard, it was worse in the backyard,” Evans said.

title: Flooding Slows Cargo Movement at Brazil Rio Grande Port
message:
Bad weather has constrained and continues to constrain cargo movement at Rio Grande, which is the fourth largest in the country for soy exports and third largest for fertilizer imports.
On Tuesday, the Rio Grande port authority had set a new draft of 12.80 meters (41.99 ft) for vessels at three grain terminals.
The Rio Grande port is located in the south of Brazil’s Rio Grande do Sul state, a big grains and meat producer and exporter.
The waters hit food silos and affected critical infrastructure, including access to the Rio Grande port.
Last week, Bunge temporarily halted its Rio Grande soy crushing facility and port terminal because forecasters predicted more rains and flooding in the region.
